sec.p: Although findings have been consistent, it is important to take into account that perceptions of risk from climate change may vary with understanding and knowledge of the phenomenon. Perceived risk is an affect heuristic, based on experiential learning and emotional response to external stimulus ( Slovic, 2009; Weber & Stern, 2011), and influenced by factors that may cause over- or under-estimation of risk. The tendency toward associative and affective processes and reliance on mediated information creates vulnerability to competing climate change frames put forth by interest groups ( Weber & Stern, 2011), and suggests that the potential influence of such groups should be examined.
